description:
It's good to see this place is still around. I found it 7 years ago when I was visiting a friend in San Francisco, and ended up at a terrible blues bar with a terrible blues band and a terrible cover charge that only twisted the knife. While there, I took out my phone and searched Yelp, and on my then-terrifically-slow 3G connection, found Geary Club about a mile and a half away. When I read the complaints about indoor smoking and rude bartenders and unfriendly patrons, I knew it was the only place nearby I would probably enjoy myself. I was not wrong. Within 20 minutes of arriving, Lillian had scolded my friend's cousin for being on her phone, yelled at someone for insulting us (the lady in question had actually just heard us say we're from Texas and was yelling that she loves Texas) and kicked everyone out of the bar. Only after being talked down - at length - by several regulars did she repent and let us all stay. 

By the end of the night, we had somehow befriended Lillian enough that when we asked where we could go to drink a fifth of whiskey we had just bought because the aforementioned cousin had taken someone from the bar to our shared hotel room for naked time, she took us nextdoor to her apartment, bade us wait til she closed the bar, then she came up and offered to cook us some pork chops, which we turned down, then we shared edibles and drank the whiskey while listening to patsy cline and talking about life and love. That night was not only the highlight of the trip, but also one of my favorite memories. I'm sad to hear Lillian is no longer at the bar, but I am incredibly happy that I got to meet her.
author: Wes D.

description:
3 things about The Geary Club:
1. This is your neighborhood dive bar. 1 TV, rail liquor selection, and bottled beer. 
2. I loved the atmosphere for a dingy dive with a great cast of characters enjoying a Friday night. 
3. Lillian has been running this joint for a while and will take good care of you. She suggests a beer and a shot Anchor Steam and a shot of Fernet Branca. 

Dont bring your date here unless you wanna test them on how down to earth they are. There are bar flys literally. But if you want a cheap drink Lillian's got you covered.
author: Zachary D.

description: It's all about June and the jukebox   There's a tiger head and wood paneling.  What more can you want from a neighborhood bar   The cash register alone is worth the price of admission
author: W M.

description:
Deepest dive in the city. 
Geary Club is the city's most cutty bar. 
This is where I go to escape the abominable wave of douchebaggery that crashes into the tenderloin on weekends. It's like a refuge for the tattered remains of San Francisco's soul. 

June the owner is a soldier and a saint
author: Ryan S.

description: Really simple and rad dive bar. I got my coffee fix at 1am after a night of drinking at some RVCA gallery show. I even sat next to a cowboy. What are the odds? Cowboys in San Francisco? I hope to spend more time at Geary Club just for the stories.
author: Laurie M.

description: I loved this little neighborhood dive bar when Lillian worked there. The new bartender is nice, but I miss Lillian's antics. She was fun to drink with, and THE number one reason to go was to hang out with Lillian and watch her sing, drink, insult customers, and play favorites with the regulars. Now that she's gone, it's just an ordinary bar. If anyone knows where Lillian is working now, please let me know!
author: Jeff K.

description: Unassuming friendly dive bar with old school decor that looks like your grandpa's cabin in the woods. No frills, good selection of drinks, nice service, and cheap drinks! Most of the patrons were chill and friendly but also a couple younger douchey drunken people in the mix
author: Christine K.

description: Affordable, great people, great vibe! And apparently they're the second smallest bar in the whole city
author: Afua D.

description: wonderful little dive bar. it's still got a soul, unlike much of the rest of SF these days.
author: Devin W.

description:
If there was such a thing as a Dive-Bar convention, I suppose Geary Club would be the Belle o' the Ball.  Also - I wonder where it would be held?  Atlantic City?  Reno?  Jacksonville, FL?  I'm not exactly sure what it would look like, but I know it would smell of:  Stale beer, old cigarette smoke, farts, and lord only knows what else.

Oh sure.  There are divier dive bars (like, where you think you might get murdered by the guy ranting to himself in the corner - eh hmm...  looking your way Jonell's), and there are certainly seedier joints.  This is a dive bar's dive bar.  On the one hand, Super Divey.  On the other hand, actually pretty classy as dive bars go.  I was told to come here on a recommendation while I was at Ha-Ra Club.  Sure enough, it's a good thing I got the tip, because I would NEVER have found it otherwise.  You know a bar can stand on it's own two legs if it does NOTHING to be noticed.

What you'll find: 

1.  Bottled Beer only (for beer - they have the hooch) - Which is fine, because they have Icey-Cold Mueller Light bottles.  (is best beer - taste a-ok's, no filling ... thanks to my Russian friend for that assist)
2.  Bartenders who think short-term bartending gigs are at least two decades.  A few nice ladies - although, I suspect you need to go at least for five years before you are considered Geary Club Elite.
3.  Neighborhood patrons.  This is a nice classic gem nestled against the back-drop on impending gentrification.
4.  A guy who calls himself "Evil Robert".  I didn't think he was that evil.  ...just saying.
5.  A bar that is open Ear-lie in the Morning.
6.  A stuffed Tiger-Head.  Named... wait for it... Tony.
author: Adam S.

description:
Best dive bar in the neighborhood. Cheap drinks (nothing on tap,) cheap jukebox (pretty diverse selection), and a never ending collection of colorful characters. We even rang in the new year here and enjoyed festive decorations and a free glass of bubbly. 

If you like hole in the wall dives, you've got to visit. If you're one of those stuck up types who get uncomfortable around real humanity, don't bother coming in. 

Cash only, the sign outside over the door only says "BAR."
author: Celina T.

description: This dive bar quickly became a favorite stop for us when in San Francisco for a couple days.  The service is friendly with a little bit of sass, and the drink prices are amazing for being in the heart of the city.  I'll make this a stop whenever I'm in SF.  The bar is not very big, but it was not crowded any of the times we went.  It has a casual, divey, neighborhood bar feel to it, which makes it a comfortable stop nearly anyone can enjoy.
author: Joshua W.

description: Amber alert! This place is awesome! Amber was fantastic and we would love to come back here. Thank you!
author: Justin B.

description:
This place is a total sh*thole and that's why I love it. 

You: "How can you love such a sh*thole?"

Me: "Cheap drinks and an awesome bartender"

What makes an awesome bartender? (in a dive bar)...
-She gave me $20 to put in the jukebox, (which is like 250 songs there), then quickly sassed all of our selections
-She was missing for the first five minutes we were there
-She was hammered
-She arm wrestled several members of our party
-She served shots that were just ginormous 
-She laughed with us... and at us

With the other patrons being cool with our shenanigans and a cute little library book exchange in the back, how can you not love this place?! Oh, you like nice things. Right. Yes, well, carry on then. Like a cheap drink at midnight and a fun place to goof? Come on over.
author: Drew A.

description:
This place is not the worst, but it's pretty close. The reason it's a two and not a one is because a) the entertainment value of watching Lillian, the bartender, is pretty fantastic and b) the juke box. 

That being said, Lillian is almost always drunk and kind of a jerk. We tried ordering a bourbon neat eight times from her before we have up and converted it to a gin and tonic. 

It also has some weird clientele. Watch your bag and your back. 

Go here if you want your patience tried and your drinks cheap. Stay away if you want anything else. 

The good: cheap drinks. 
The bad: the fear of looking Lillian in the eye. You think she has snakes for hair and you may turn into stone. Your move.
author: Amanda B.

description: If you don't like this place you don't belong in a bar and you're everything wrong with your generation.
author: Lucia A.

description:
I don't recall how or why everything went down the way it did that night but, I was with Drew A and friends when we came in. Read his review for a more accurate description as he remembers far more than I do about this divey gem.

Yes the bartender was schmammered and she did arm wrestle most members of our party but, the thing I love her for most is that $20 for the juke box. No touch tunes here, you flip the album covers looking for your favorite jams like back in old days... or at least the 90's. From this point on I was dead set on creating the most epic playlist to ever be heard at Geary Club and Judging by the fact that $20 in that bad boy got us something like 400 songs, they're likely still jamming to our groups musical stylings as we speak... I hope you like Van Morrison.

We all had a blast here and if it wasn't for photo evidence I may have told you it never happened. Instead, it did happen and I don't regret one song I played on that juke box no matter what you say.

Pro Tip: If you want to die... order shots! She might as well have handed us each a bottle to suck down.
author: Scotty C.

description:
Lilian makes the Geary Club what it is! 

It's folks like Amanda B who really should not bother coming to the Geary Club but head up the street to Rye. 

Leave this one to the locals!

Update: The Bar has lost all it's charm. Taken over by fucktards from Aces.
author: Jill F.

description: I love this place. My only issue is I am a writer and the delusional owner thinks I am a drug dealer. I have no idea why. I still like it and hope it's saved from the Geary street gentrification. But I've never sold anything of any value in my life, let alone drugs.
author: Skinkton Z.

description:
This place is a shithole...but that's why its good. If you don't get that then you're probably a douche. 

One of the last real dive bars in the area.
author: Monsieur_Meursault _.

description: A five star jukebox. Serves ice cold Coors Banquet from an ice cold cooler. Lighting perfected. Geary Club is one of the finest joints on the strip.
author: Alexander T.

description: A small, quiet dive that is a welcome respite from the precious little bars that have proliferated in the TL. Going here is like stepping back into 1983. Prices are fair, pours are strong and the staff is good - especially the German woman. She's the best.
author: Larry S.

description:
This tiny dive bar is exactly what you want in a dive bar: cheap drinks, intimate but comfortable ambiance, and a great bartender. Lilliana, the bartender, is truly amazing. An enormous amount of energy, fun, chatty. For me, she made the Geary Club awesome. 

Fun tip: challenge Lilliana to an arm wrestle. She will surprise you
author: Erick T.

description:
This bar has all the triple D's (and not in the Guy Fieri way); it's dark, depressing, and dank. The $3.75 well drinks make this place kind of bearable, but it's certainly no place you'd take a date or go to unwind after a day at the office. This joint is pretty much a locals only dive for those with more gray hairs than not and it's got a stuffed tiger head on the wall and a bartender that looks like a former tweaker. The door is almost purposefully unmarked to keep the curious out, so look for it half way between Leavenworth and Hyde real carefully.  Our hero would kindly recommend passing it by for some other much better dives in the area.

PROS:
- Cheap drinks.

CONS:
- Small place.
- Depressing ambiance.
- Not much of a lively crowd.
author: Albert W.

description: I love you Geary Club!  Lillian is a gem and I always have a great time here. We talk memories of Hungary and Germany whenever I stop by.  She has been working this place for years and is generous with the jukebox money!  Do not talk on your cell phone in here or Lillian will let you know what she thinks about that.  Real jukebox! Salty bartendresses. A great place to come and drink alone since you will always make a new friend from the neighborhood.  This place is old school and increasingly rare in the rapidly sterilizing bay area. Respect!
author: Tabby K.

description:
Popped in last night on for my friend's birthday since we've heard this place called a hidden gem. The clearly completely fucked up bartender asked for our ID's. Quick to draw, I handed my ID first. Assuming she'd take a look and hand it back, I reached my hand out to get it back and the woman literally slapped my hand and slurred it would take a minute. 

15 seconds after running all five of our IDs, she insisted she hadn't run them all. We mentioned that she did get all of them and started to pull them back out when she began screaming at us to get out of the bar. 

We will not be going back. If you want a dive in the TL try Whiskey Thieves or High Tide.
author: Kate B.

description: After you have spent all your money in the city and are down to your last dollar you can probably still afford to get a drink at this little spot. I spent a week in SF and found this place on the last night and it felt like home.
author: Kail L.

description:
This is what people mean when they say dive bar. No frills, just cheap, strong drinks and people wanting to hang out and do their own thing.

The bartender, who people constantly refer to here, is absolutely fitting for the place. Friendly smile and eager to be your buddy while you sink your pints. 

And yes, they do allow smoking. I think if I was here too long, it'd probably bother me, but it's not bad when you're there for your last couple of drinks for the night.

It's not somewhere I'd go all the time, but certainly a welcome change from some of the over-frequented, overly hip places in sf. next time i'm there, i'm going to have look at this jukebox...
author: Jon T.

description:
Went here last night with my girlfriend.. decent dive bar, just not much going on. The bartender was a tiny middle aged woman that seemed tweaked out. She was frequently mumbling incomprehensible phrases. 

The drinks were decently priced, probably a little more expensive than I would like a dive bar to serve, but hey, it's sf. As for the taste of the drinks, spend the extra dollar or two and DON'T GET THE WELL drinks. My girlfriend ordered a rum and coke and it was terrible.
author: Peter H.

description:
"The introverts' bar" was one fellow-patron's description.  The Geary Club is a special place, dissimilar from the other bars in the Tendernob.  Here people are quite friendly, but not at all outgoing or pushy-"friendly".  Sit for a while, think, nurse your (cheap) drink - and when you actually have something to say, say it.  This bar is much quieter than most; but the conversations much better.  

Here you will hear the sound of people speaking standard American English,tho not always with an American accent.  There's none of the hideous Stanford-drawl of the Marina douches, nor the equally hideous Norcal-snark of the Mission iClones; nor any incomprehensible ghettobabble; nor the crazy bum-gibberish endemic to the TL.  It's a subtle thing, but the sound of a place contributes a great deal to its character.  At the Geary one rarely hears the grating tones of pretension, snobbery, or willful idiocy.

The volume on the (fairly decent, and appropriate olde-timey) juke box is kept low.  The bartenders can control it, but flat out refuse to turn it up loud.  The clock on the wall is set to Network Standard Time, none of that imaginary Bar Time bullshit.  There's no sign on the door, and there's a tiger head named "Tony" mounted over the bar.  The bartenders are all older women, one of them notable as a cougar, all decent & polite people.  

The patrons are a pretty broad cross section of the City.  Taxi drivers, laborers, ad men, programmers, students, artists..  anyone who loves cheap beer and good company.  Natives, immigrants, economic refugees from the flyover side by side.  

Not to say it's a perfect place.  There is only one variety of wine, some pink girlie stuff I don't want to drink.  A cheap red wine would be greatly appreciated, if management is listening.  Beer selection is not huge, but at least a bit eccentric.  They serve Coors - not Coors Light like everywhere else, just plain old Coors.
author: Jason M.

description: Stumbled upon this gem! We came in because it literally just said bar on the outside and was a small little door. amazing dive bar with real people and an inviting vibe. Both bartenders were great and made me feel at home.
author: Amanda G.

description:
Highlights of the evening were watching the drunk tiny bartender drop our IDs onto a machine that reads in huge letters our age, sitting next to a woman with tears roll down her face singing roxanne and arguing it's merit as a good song with bartender, smelling tv dinner being microwaved, paying less for a mixed drink than a bottle of Bud, and the bathroom looking like Ronald McDonald's. 

xoxoxo
author: Brittany L.

description:
Oh hell yes. 

I definitely want to be a member of this club. 

I can't decide which is more awesome, the lack of any signage out front, the ashtrays made from tin-foil, or the fact that some dude at the bar bet Aaron V $2 that he couldn't beat up Katie S.

Or maybe it's simply the fact that the name Geary Club inspires visions of a swank, upscale, pretentious private establishment when it's actually a real dive bar (not some fake hipster bullshit, but an honest to goodness dive like the Ha-Ra).

Where do I sign up?
author: Don B.

description:
I gots memories of entering here in it's S**thole glory (which has nuthin' to do with glory holes) I recall sitting at the bar after having rub my front and behind on the other patrons because the place is a tighter fit than . . . (use your own disgusting metaphor). I gots a couple boiler makers for me and my two companions (girl X and boy Y) Those went down unsmoothly so Y orders round two and that's just as tough.
I mention we were already stupid when we came in?
Next thing I knew X was buying the third round.
X pukes on the sidewalk, Y collapses onto the bar (I think) I don't know where I went but according to X and Y I left and didn't return for some time. None of this makes sense which is why FIVE STARS BABY. Geary Club you enabled the worst in us! Next time I come here I hope I don't remember it at all!

I wish they would rename the boiler maker after me.
author: Alexander R.

description: I took off my clothes and wore a tutu for more free drinks than I or anybody with me needed. Great times!
author: Dr. J.

description: For all of you "out of towners" and haters...you really should not come to this bar. There is a a reason it is called a "local dive bar.
author: Jack F.

description:
This place is an outstanding locals dive. Sadly, you can't smoke in there anymore because a bunch of people posted about it on yelp. 

There is still a fake tiger's head, an old juke box, and stiff drinks.
author: Slim P.

description: My Old Man loved this place. I come here to Honor him. Old American Rock and Roll Dive Bar!
author: Everette R.

description: I've been coming here since 1980.The Geary Club does not is not a dedicated follower of fashion.Check it out.
author: David B.

description: pretty damn awesome like something you will find in Wisconsin or the up. grandmas serving with attitude for 40 years. jukebox. thrills. get told its time to go if you don't order enough and clog up the bar.
author: B S.

description:
This place is a total divey shithole filled with raging alcoholics, and I say that in the nicest, most positive way possible. 

The woman who is usually behind the bar seems to be attempting to drink more than anybody else. They let you smoke in here and provide odd little tinfoil ashtrays. The jukebox doesn't have any music on it that was recorded prior to 1989 and most of it was made by people who are now dead after long battles with substance abuse. The drinks are cheap and strong and they do actually offer you a free one (occasionally) if they can tell you're going to be there a while. 

Not for the weak of heart. Abandon all hope, ye who enter here. It's awesome.
author: Drew H.

description:
Divey to a whole other level, the Geary Club makes the Nightcap seem like an AA meeting and Whiskey Thieves look like the Vatican.  

As close to a hole in the wall as you can possibly imagine.  They smoke inside - a lot.  I'm pretty sure you'd get your ass beat if you complained.  And I'll bet real money the people beating your ass are ex cops. Or union reps. Or made men.  Something like that.

This place has *character* - and very cheap drinks.  If I was ten times the drunkard I am, I'd sooo be here every night.
author: Nathan M.

description: Best fucking dive bar in San Fran...  So bad it was good~!
author: Dean P.

description:
An unmarked entrance faces Geary street.  It's open door welcomes visitors, but it's dwelling-like storefront is devoid of signs, windows, and neon.  The sounds of laughter and music beckon visitors to enter, but the unmarked exterior makes first time visitors apprehensive of what might be inside.  Bar?  Restaurant? Private Club? Somebody's Garage?  I stumbled by this place on a Saturday afternoon, and couldn't resist casting a pensive glance inside.  What dwelt within? Naught more than a neighborhood bar, a sight that didn't reveal itself until my pupils dilated enough to see amongst the interior lighting, which is equally sparse as the exterior decor.

The long, narrow room reaches deep into the building it dwells in.  It's dark near the entrance, gets darker further in, and becomes *really* dark near the back.  Modest-sized TV's sit at either end of the bar...get a seat near them if you want to watch a game.  The interior is definitely old-school....cheap simulated wood paneling on the sides with stucco up top.  The barmaids are quick, friendly, and cute-as-a-button.  Liquor selection is average, and I didn't see any beer on tap.

The crowd I saw was mixed, and somewhat older.  Neither the beautiful people from the trendier part of Geary nor the freaks from the Tenderloin were present.  A younger guy sat on one side of me, and a lady in her 70's on the other.  Striking up baseball chitchat with the younger guy proved futile...all I got in return was a punkish gruffness.  The lady on the other side proved very talkative.....in baseball, history, and politics.

Bluntly put, it's a dank, dark, somewhat characterless space whose only saving graces are the bartenders. One might see it as an upgrade from the Tenderloin, or a refuge from terminally trendy spots several blocks down Geary.

And empty beer and four point lead by the Phillies over the Giants signaled it was time to move along.  I pondered the Geary Club's virtues as I walked out the door, racking my brains for a reason to praise it.  Halfway down the block, I'd drawn a blank.  Come the first street-crossing, I found more important things to think about....
author: Mike W.

description:
Small place with a lot of regulars...

Granted, I'm no drinker and amazed at how some places stay in business. Geary Club is a testament to longevity! I was taken by the faux taxidermied tiger head atop the bar, personally. The bartender is an older lady that wears skin tight clothes and is happy to get pretty tipsy along side you, if you're good people. As tiny as it is, you will still feel pretty comfortable considering the space. You won't find trendy folks here either. Just, well, 'real' people. Nobody trying to check out a scene. If anything, all types of individuals walk in and pay no mind to anyone else in there. Very low key and very much nestled in the Tenderloin like a little kitty that has found a place to nap...for a long time.

Be warned though, people smoke in the bar and if you are averse to smoking, smokers and your clothes smelling like smoke in the morning, this place is not for you.
author: Dorothy S.

description:
Santacon stop #2

It was a little weird finding this hole-in-the-wall bar with no signage on Geary. I mean, I was walking one moment and then the next moment, I was swooped into this half door entry way into a little room with walls decked in SF spirit and alochol. This place was original gangster -- I don't know of any other bars that still allow its patrons to smoke inside...! While I don't like smoke indoors, the lady bartender laid down a strong Seagrams7 and ginger for me that was paid for by a gentleman that was in love with the Raiders even though there was plenty of 49ers memorabilia on the walls... This place is like one of those bars that will remember your name and drink -- like Cheers, but not in Boston -- and yes, I will definitely be back.
author: Nicole P.

description:
No signs
No lights
Hidden behind a tree
Off of Geary
Is a little club
Hidden within the walls
Is a little bar
You would never discover
Without word of another.
Inside these walls
Many stories emerge.
Cynthia 
On her taxi driving
Cursing all bikers
Against their
Unrealistic antics
Cruising the wrong way. 
Cups of wine
Stories of bourgeoisie
All non drivers to her
Are just plain crazy. 
Harriet 
Behind the bar
Serving us drinks
40 years 
She has lived
In the Tenderloin 
A life devoted
To serving drinks.
She lights a cigarette 
So I sip on my bourbon
Where I am transported 
To the decades' past.
Red lips she wanted
Constructed on the toilet
So all guys know
Where to pee.
Golden streamers
Creepers upon creepers
The heart of the TL 
The Geary Club
Truly provides
Tales of the tell all.
Stop by 
I must suggest.
Relax
To hear true life
To hear true inner-city 
To hear true San Francisco.
author: Jon-o G.

description:
As someone who just moved to the area, and is still broke from the moving costs, I've been hitting all of the dive bars in the neighborhood, and Geary Club is still my favorite by far.

Here's all you need to know:

The drinks are really cheap.
Most of the time you can smoke inside, and even watch the bartender make your ashtray out of tin foil.
Lillian is the greatest bartender ever, mostly because she's probably more drunk than you are, and yet she does an excellent job of attending to everyone at the bar.
The jukebox has a badass selection of music from the 60s-80s.
It's a great place to go with a small group of friends, or even by yourself.
It's impossible to find, so it never gets too crowded.
There's a stuffed lion head above the bar.
author: Arjun S.

description:
Yes.

I'm so happy that this is in my neighborhood... or, should I say, I'm in their neighborhood. Don't be deceived: this IS a dive bar. No two ways about it. If you're expecting the Bigfoot, get the fuck out. If you're gonna get picky about your cocktails, get the fuck out. If you just wanna get down... well, they have booze. Radness you bastards.
author: Roy M.

description: Oh, snaps! Forgot to mention that the have a library! Yeah, it rules. Perhaps a drunken book swap is more accurate, but nonetheless, they've got reading material. Gotta love it!
author: Ruggy J.

description:
I've had Yelper's block recently. I've spent way too many minutes staring at the computer screen, fingers frozen over the keyboard. The few reviews I've cranked out have left me feeling 'meh' so I decided to "go back to my roots" (a late night week day drinking festivity that involved me acting like a total girl). Yep, fueled by a much needed chat fest, continuous vodka tonics and snappy attitude from every angle of the bar I could feel the magic of Geary Club thaw my Yelper's block.
 
If you don't know what kind of a place Geary Club is, I can sum it up for you fast: it is a bar to get your dive drinking on! 

Now I'll elaborate. This place is "classy", like the same level of classy an afternoon shift stripper with a missing front tooth and an eye patch is. There is no shame. You know, a bar where some truly quality drinking takes place. One of those multipurpose bars where your mindset can be up for a cheery day of drinking to the truly depressing "I don't give a flyin' f*ck anymore, I just want to be loaded" as you slurp away at your drink and stare off forlornly into space or a recovery/ recollection drink from the night before. It's a place where you get your drink with a bar stool and counter space. A bar where no natural light has the strength to make it past the first foot of the door (a special bar vortex if you will).  

Yes you can smoke in here and yes, as a smoker I appreciate this. Even as a non smoker you should be able to appreciate this too because this little drinking palace is in the heart of TL. One glance around the room or pop outside should tell you the funk you WOULD be smelling if this was a non smoking establishment. And of course there is a certain delight in ashing into a piece of foil bent into an ashtray (I told you, this place just exudes true class). The crowd is an healthy slice of the local neighborhood. $20 can get you 3 to 4 rounds (with tip) for your group or your own sorry ass. Of course, you can be like me and my friends and smartly invest in the jukebox so you can have a soundtrack to your commiserating.

The best part of Geary Club though is the "on the border of kicking your ass" feel to the place. Whether it be tough as nails bartendresses, the attitude of the other patrons and the neighborhood or the aftermath of too many well drinks, you can pretty much assure yourself you will have your ass handed to you in some way or another if you aren't in check. But really, sometimes we have to learn our lessons the hard way no?
author: Veronica G.

description:
If you look up "dive bar" in the dictionary, it would have a picture of the Geary Club. No bigger than a studio apartment, it is one of those rare places that look a little scary from the outside, but once inside, you feel like you're part of the gang.  From the little twinkly lights over the bar, to the rockin jukebox time-warped from the 80's. It's a nice place to round out a bar crawl, especially if you only have a few dollars in your pocket (two drinks-$7!)

Lillian is one of the sweetest bartenders I've ever met. She treated me like I've been a regular for years.  That woman knows how to work a makeup brush--she can go head to head with the fashion industry pros!
author: Lisa R.

description:
Place stinks like SMOKE. This is what bars used to smell like...why go back to your clothes stinking the next morning. Stay away!!!!

Shit
author: Brian G.

description:
This isn't your standard wannabe dive bar that really is just dirty instead of divey.  The drinks are cheap, the mirrored beer signs are authentic, and the crowd is made up of folks from every walk of life.  The bartender lady is someone you could see shooting the shit with every night after work, ruminating on life, until you have a really really really bad day and find yourself bawling your eyes out on her bosom.

I give it four stars - for some reason, I just don't think 5 stars does it the right kind of justice.  Weird and illogical, I know, because honestly I love this place.  But it just feels right.  A five star review might get read just because it's 5 stars - like a book with a great cover.  But Geary Club doesn't have a great cover.  You just have to dive in and discover its perfections without ever seeing a bright sign out front or a ridiculous line out the door or 5 stars on its reviews.
author: Audrey T.

description:
This place evokes memories of childhood. No, it is not what you think. I did not drink as a small child. But I did....

.....play hide and seek. So does this bar, what, with no sign whatsoever you have a hard time finding it when you are actually seeking it.

......watch The Wizard of Oz, and remember a little line that went "Lions and Tigers and Bears, Oh MY!". Well, they have the tiger anyhow.

....find myself surrounded by my parents friends a lot. The average age of the clientele puts them in my parents age range.

......work hard for my allowance and spend it on candy. Well, now its alcohol but, just like when I was a kid, a few dollars goes a long way.

......read Alice in Wonderland. This bar was modeled after a rabbit hole. I know for a fact that I have taken the red pill when I walk in here because there is no possible way this bar is meant for full size human beings. You could also assume, once you look around a bit that there are definitely many people in here that have also journeyed down the "rabbit hole".
author: Drue C.

description:
Finally I made it to Geary Club!

A rainy Monday night after having a weird "building party" at my house.
I was already a bit drunk and the Geary Club was right there with me, with my rain boots, rain jacket and a beanie I looked like a twelve year old kid entering this small bar with a foggy and drunk atmosphere, PERFECT.

I am not famous for being shy so of course I made a friend, an interesting friend.

I like this place, I like the size of it, I like the "tipsy" bartender and it felt like back in the days when you smelled like an ashtray coming home from the pub.

Ps: If you ask me what a "building party" is, I might tell you!
author: cecilia k.

description:
H ip or not, Hot or not,
O ld and young, 
L ocal watering hole,
E veryone fits right in, even me?

I gnoring the tiger head up on the wall is tough.
N o signage out front makes this place a difficult find.

W ells for cheap. Other drinks also.
A Tenderloin-flavored establishment. 
L ose the group. Come alone or bring one other. 
L ose the attitude too. Nobody cares.

This place wins in the "'DARK DIVE, JUST DRINK, DON'T DRIVE" category. It is a bit smoky, despite the "No Smoking" signs outside. I need to take a shower and wash my sweatshirt afterwards, but that's no problem at all. Sometimes you need to find an escape like this, a spot others won't expect to find you.
author: Tinna H.

description:
What's the deal with people bitching about one of the few bars in the city where a smoker can manifest their filthy habit with out slinking out the door in shame?  Come on folks, go to Jillian's or John Collins or something, people!

Geary Club is a dank little tool-shed of a bar.  The videocrack machine is running on a 286.  MGD and an Old Overholt come in at about a ten spot.  They've got Professor Longhair on the jukebox.  The staff is friendly, if hard as nails.  In other words, this is one of the city's best bars.  Don't come here if you're a whiny little yelp-bitch.
author: Chadwick C.

description:
A friend asked me if I'd ever been here and while I regularly hang out in this neighborhood I'd never heard of this place. I was told that there was a "hot" German bartender that gets drunk and occasionally randomly "tongues" customers. I was told it was a rowdy TL dive bar.  Isn't it interesting how different people perceive things so differently?

The bartender was very pleasant but not what I'd call "hot". I thought perhaps the hot bartender had the night off until the one that was there told someone that she had to work a 12 hour shift because mom wasn't feeling good. Unless mom is an unusually attractive sixty something this must have been the "hot" bartender. I did see her get very cozy with one of the customers. Also, not that it matters, but I know Germans and I'm not convinced she even had a German accent; it sounded eastern European to me although I make no claim of accent expertise.

The Geary club is a typical dive bar with a cliquey set of regulars. They don't have any beer on tap if that's important to you. Finally this place is a little smoky, how did I stand going out before they banned smoking in bars? Just a little smoke is intolerable to me now. 

Since this place is so close to one of my favorite bars, Edinburgh castle, I doubt I'll be back. In fact I'd rather go to Ha-Ra just a block up the street.
author: Manny F.

description:
Sorry Yelp.  You let me down.  

We were looking for a place near Bourbon & Branch that might not be as crowded, or that just offered a change for our second round of drinks.  I found Geary Club nearby with rave reviews.

Maybe it's just an off night, or maybe the juxtaposition with the swank vibe of B&B was just too much, but we walked in, stayed for 5 minutes, and left without getting drinks.  It stunk like an ashtray from 1975, and I am NOT the type that is usually sensitive to stuff like that.  Maybe I've been living in SF too long, but I felt like I was going to hurl after a minute of breathing that stuff and could feel it seeping into my skin.  To top it off, folks were having a good old fashioned bar fight at the entrance, and the other guys in the place gave me the creeps enough that I shuddered on the way out.  

I am so tempted to give my first 1 star rating, but I guess I must have missed something based on everyone's review.  Plus we didn't even have drinks, so I guess that's not fair.  But to be honest, I still feel sick and I'm sad that had to cap off what was otherwise an excellent day.  Pretty sure I'm not going back.
author: Danna G.

description: This is the dive bar of all dive bars. I walked in solo one night just because I had to see the tiger's head on the wall that I read about on Yelp. I intended to stay for just a few beers but ended up staying for the Giants game that was on tv. I felt like a regular by the end of the night. I was also pretty drunk when I left. It was fun and I felt very welcome. Check it out if you are into dive bars.
author: Paul G.

description:
Some guys think they're being slick when they are in a crowded place and they try to get past a girl and they "accidentally" grab their ass or lean into the boobage. 

This place is perfect for being on the receiving end of those small invasions of the personal bubble. 

I mean hey, the bar takes up 80% of the room! If you can't beat 'em.....
author: Jay H.

description:
At this point I'm one bourbon, two shots of fernet and three anchor steams deep.  Sitting at the bar, I lean over and order another beer.

ME:  "Can I get another Anchor please?"

BARTENDER:  "We're sold out, we've got Bud Light, Coors, Anchor Steam, Corona ... "

ME:  (interrupting)  "I'll have an Anchor Steam, please."

BT:  "Coming up!"  (reaches down to fridge, comes up, hands me a Heineken)

ME:  ... (stares blankly, thinks for about 5 seconds, proceeds to drink Heineken)

This review is intented to be more of a reflection on what the Geary Club is and why I like it; a place where you drink.  A place where you drink, even if you get the wrong drink.  You know a place is great if your taxi driver says it's where she goes to drink everytime she gets off of work at 6am.

There is nothing else.

There's no darts, no foosball, no shuffle board.  Nothing to engender yells of victory or curses of defeat.

There's no dancing either.  Even if you really wanted to and the place was half full, there's just no room.   

There is photohunt, but that is a solemn thinking man's game.

All that is left is drinking.  Drinks.  $3 well shots all the time.  Bottled Beers as low as $2.50.  

You come, you converse and you drink.  That is all.
author: Steven R.

description:
This place completely lived up to my expectations and the most amazing thing is, my expectations could not have possibly been any lower.

So I was going to dinner at Le Colonial and I wanted to hit up a dive bar in the hood beforehand.  I did a search for bar on Yelp in the Tenderloin and Geary Club popped up with 4-1/2 stars.  I started reading the reviews and thought to myself "Wow, a dive bar like this is a dream come true".  

The bar is a really hard place to find.  No sign.  Tiny bar with local regulars who like to chat it up.  The tiger head of Shere Khan from the Jungle Book was staring at me as I sipped on my $3.00 vodka soda.  I only had one drink, small conversation with one of the regulars, inhaled lots of smoke, listened to some craptastic songs on the jukebox and pounded my cheap libation.

I left the Geary Club feeling an overwhelming sense of satisfaction and a strong desire to go back as soon as I can.  As my man Beck sang....I think I'm in LOVE!
author: Christina S.

description: this is how bars in the tenderloin tended to be when i lived there. not so anymore. i love this place...i love the bartenders, the jukebox, even the tiny squares of TP in the bathroom that remind me of high school. don't ever change or disappear, geary club!
author: Kate W.

description:
At the time of this review I saw there were 49 other reviews.  How in the hell did this place ever attract 49 patrons with internet access?  

My favorite dive bar on the planet was a place on the North Sea in a town called South Shields, England.  My old man sent me there right out of college to become the Taco King of northeast England (it's a long story). If you've ever been to So. Shields you'd understand why a taco stand wouldn't work in a bitter-ass cold, god-forsaken, industrial crap-hole of a town.  You walk into this bar (I can't remember the name of it-it was 20+ years ago) and the people there all smelled bad, their teeth were rotted, a few were wearing eye-patches, some had a bullet wound or two, I even saw a peg leg.  And I'm only talking about the women in the place.    

ANYWAY: here's why I love my wife.... I convinced her to come to a dive bar (which is now my new favorite dive bar) I found on Yelp.  She went to the art museum earlier in the day without me and was going on and on about Frida Kahlo.  I wanted to give her an extra dose of culture (she trusts me on these matters, hence the deep love) so we dragged our asses up the hill. We walked into the filthiest of the filthy, grimiest of the grimy, smokiest of the smoky, ten seat (?) shit-box you'd ever hope to find.  

When my wife (or any chick) walks into a bar (any bar) says, "I can't decide what I want",  that's her way of defaulting into ordering a cosmo.  A quick look around The Geary Club told me ordering a cosmo would get her ass kicked.

Round One:
I scanned the bar and saved my wife getting the crap kicked out of her and ordered her an amaretto sour.  

Lillian the bartender asks: "What's in it?" 

So we got our 9 ounces of amaretto with a splash of sour and I got my Anchor Steam.  By now we had settled in and we were right at home having cocktails with Lillian. When I say having drinks with the bartender, I mean drinks with the bartender- she had 2 or 3 drinks of her own going and I have to guess she was on her fourth or fifth of the day.    

Round Two:
After peering the smoke to see what else they had behind the bar I saw the only other chick-drink-that-won't-get-your-ass-kicked Baileys and Bushmills.  Next round I got her about 5 ounces of Baileys with 4 ounces of a Bushmills float.  

Round Three:  We came back after dinner (exceptional Thai just down the block) and Lillian asks, "Are you drinking the same?"  So she starts pouring a Baileys and Bombay as if people order it every day.  Looking around the bar I could see how it could happen.
author: Eddie T.

description:
Two out of the three times I was at the Geary club, I pissed off the locals.  Really, I'm sorry.

First time, I lit up a clove ciggie (they're pretty lenient on the health dept codes at Geary Club), and accidentally blew smoke too close to this guy.  Eh it was nothing that a free MGD didn't resolve.

Second time I was talkin to this guy about how the place had no sign out front.  He told me that it was burned up in a lightning storm.

"A f*cking lightning storm?"

Guess this guy was super old fashioned or just plain wierd.  He got extremely angry at me for cursing.  He was trying to get me thrown out for saying the F word.

Eh, whatever.  It's a good drown-your-sorrows-coal-miner bar, and the old Russian (?) woman who runs the place is very nice.
author: Rocco B.

description:
Everything at this dark unmarked bar is short.  The counter, the seats, the bartenders, the little French doorway.  Your life expectancy.  Very small.

Drinks are heavy, Geary Street pour, Eddie Street prices. $4 for 2-3 ounces of call.

At any given time you see a gay kid, an emo couple, an old businessman, a street crazy.  When the Abba or Patsy Cline rolls on they all sing at the same time like some warped Sesame Street.

To say everyone is local is an understatement.  Everyone is on a half mile tether.

Note the singluar.  No room for duplication.  If there's two of you, you have to find somewhere else.
author: Gil S.

description:
This is the crappiest bar on the Geary Mindslide Strip. I have seen some major alcoholic delusion in this bar...RIP Belva. 

Yah, Lillian rocks. Any bartender that keeps giving me $$ to keep the Stones on the jukebox is alright in my book.

Warning, however: I don't know what the hell is going on here lately, but the last two times I've been in, they've been upset at rowdy drinking and lively conversation. As is happening with the Brown Jug, I think the plethora of "normal people" coming into these bars is bringing the regs down and they're fighting back by squeezing you out if you're being raucous. 

Just last week I was there with a friend and ended up talking to these loud but good-hearted Australian dudes and MAN were the people at the bar irritated at our having a good time. June was pissy, and I ended up totally having to like, apologize to some of the regs there for being too loud. 

It didn't used to be like that. It's kind of a really weird change to have occurred.
author: SheRat R.

description:
Christ I love this place. SF hipsters call places like Hemlock or Zeitgeist a "dive bar." I call shenanigans. This is a true dive bar. Nothing fancy. Stones on the jukebox. $3 Dewars. A men's room with one of those giant old school rotating giant towel things. Surly drunks. No Marina types. Not even many Mission hipster types. Generally you, the bartender (who rocks), two people getting into a real fight, and a thick cloud of smoke.

Horatio Alger stuff folks. This is it.
author: Richard H.

description:
I just kind of find this bar depressing.  However, I'm kind of having a conniption over why that is as it's gotten such high praise from others.  Possibilities:

1. People seem to be praising this place for how gritty it is.  Maybe growing up in middle-of-nowhere Midwest, I was exposed to actual gritty bars so this place isn't so much of a novelty as it is for other people.  I think this sentiment could be the same that Ian H. is saying by calling it "run of the mill."  

2. Don't get me wrong, I'm probably one of the biggest endorsers of smoking for being a non-smoker, however the smoke just seemed trite in this bar. Like it was trying too hard to be smoky.  Does that even make sense?

3. The DC smoking ban has ruined me. I'm a complete herb now.

4.  Maybe I'm all wrong and I actually would like this place normally but just not that night.  This could have been it. I won't put it past me. You don't either.
author: Kyle R.

description:
Sadly, this is the one bar on Geary street that I have NEVER BEEN IN. But I love it. I love this bar like the grandparent you never got to meet. 

The lack of a sign makes it an eight star joint.
author: I M.

description: Great place. I wish there is more places like that one left in the city. I was staying at Adams Mark hotel, and walked down the hill just to see this place. Not much to see - small bar, however locals are great characters, they love to engage in the conversation. I stayed for couple of hours and had wonderful time. No more smoking at the bar - need to go outside. I will be back again on my next trip to San Francisco.
author: Goran G.

description: Were it not for my appreciation of mom & pop businesses, this place would get 1 one star. The split door giving you a peek into this sliver of a bar. Consider it your chance to turn away. It's patroned by a very mature crowd. On a Tuesday night the bartender filling in looked like he'd been retired for 20 years. I don't mind sitting at a dingy old bar with people in their 60s and above, but  combined with the dinge and the smoke there was a very depressing vibe of lost dreams and aspirations. *Shudder*
author: Kim K.

description:
Geary "Club," eh? My, that sounds fancy. Is this a gleaming chrome night "club," replete with sexxxy dancers and $10 soju cocktails? Or perhaps a high-class country "club," where Kip and I can shoot a round of 18 holes and repair to the lounge to quaff G&Ts and watch some polo on the telly?

Hardly.

The Geary Club is so understated that it doesn't even bother to have a sign. In fact, the only signage it seems to have anywhere is a piece of paper tacked to an inside wall with the handwritten message: "NEW - DIET COKE." Yep, they're proud to be upgrading their selections to include diet sodas. Next step: Courvoisier on tap?

Seriously, this place is so small, if you bring 3 friends and a shoulder bag with you, it suddenly feels claustrophobic. The only decorations are some old 49ers memorabilia and a string of Xmas lights. And the drinks are cheap enough that your wallet won't feel like it's been on hunger strike at the end of the night.

Nothin' special. Just a tiny shoebox with booze. Me like. 

Only time will tell if this miniscule and elusive sub-club will keep its secret...or if the increasing waves of Trendyloin slummers ruin it. All it takes is, oh, 2 bimbos and 1 frat boy to make the Geary Club suddenly feel like a nightmare. Hence I give it a mere three stars --- to keep the easy people away.

I hate this place! Go somewhere else!
author: John G.

description:
I love Lillian!  She is the best bartendress.  And she just shakes her head when we mention Carl.  

The bathrooms are actually nice, which means a lot to this gal.  The jukebox is great, and if it doesn't work, the bartenders will give you money to put more songs in.
author: Priya R.

description: Atmospheric, wonderful!  A nod to the past of what San Francisco bars should be but alas are no more.  Quirky fun.  Everyone can feel at ease in Geary Club--from dilettantes to derelicts.  All are welcome.  Only those with attitude would have a problem.  Good-priced drinks and great music.
author: QuodE D.

description:
When I lived in Boulder, Colorado I always dreamed of living in San Francisco so that I could constantly go to cool "rock n' roll" bars like the Hemlock, Casanova and Edinburgh Castle. When I finally got there in May 2005, I realised that people that typically go to those bars are douche-bags. I felt the need to expand my horizons and the first person to help me do this was this fall down drunk friend of mine who lived a block and half from this place she called "The Geary Club" and thanks to this girl I have a new favorite bar.

First of all, she introduced me to the first smoking-friendly bar that I had been to in San Francisco. This was a huge relief for me as I was getting tired of the cramped smoking-room at the Hemlock. 

The other wonderful thing about the Geary Club is that there are always middle-aged men who have the best wisdom free of charge. 

The bartenders are great, especially Lily who is this German-born lady who I always picture in my mind eating a big-ass soup in a cup. Drinks are always cheap at this place and my only complaint about the selection of booze is that they don't carry Pabst Blue Ribbon but they have every shitty American beer that you can find in the grocery store. They serve Fernet, Ketel One, Jack Daniels, etc. but no Pernod. I guess the way it goes is that they ain't gonna switch up the way they've been doing things just because I happen to think Pabst is the best liquid I've put down my throat since I got weened off the teet. 

I still can't get over the fact that people in their 80's still go to bars to get drunk. I wonder what their one-night stands are like now that I think about it. Thinking about the great octogenerian regulars at the Geary Club makes me wish I didn't live in Yountville these days.
author: Nessim H.

description: We walked in and immediately felt at home,not our home, but someones' home.    Lillian was bar tending and she's so sweet and friendly... she talked to us as if we were regulars, we felt connected immediately.  Good place to go to be yourself.  Everyone here is real... There was something in the air you usually don't find in SF bars.
author: Miriam M.

description:
Shh! Don't Yelp this! I wanna keep my seat!

Well, since it's been done...

Another friendly neighborhood bar, most customers are regular. They were warm and friendly and welcomed me immediately. If you want to make the saucy German bartender Lilian really happy, you'll play some Rolling Stones or some 50's song she can sing along to. (And, if you stay longer than a few minutes, you'll hear the tiger growl noise she makes). I can't believe I've been in the neighborhood for so many years, and never knew this place existed.
author: Nick M.

description:
Oh man i forgot about this place! We somehow ended up here during Love Fest '07 and even though i was still reeling a bit from witnessing my first circle jerk (really), and messy feelings about a boy (le sigh), i could still appreciate the amazing fun sketchiness of Geary Club. 

This place is like drinking in a closet.... in a strangely delightful sort of way. I heard the bartender's some kind a legend but didn't get the full experience while i was there. Actually.... i don't really remember much about the bar, except for its closet-ness and weird small glasses, but a good time was had by all. In the middle of the afternoon. I think that's typical.

Oh yeah, i remember it being kind of smoky. So that's gross.. loses a star for that.
author: Jordan B.

description:
Last night we decided to try Rye.  Suffice to say, I wasn't too impressed with Rye and we left after a single drink.  

Well, as we were walking down to one of dozen watering holes in the area, we happen upon what looks to be an un-marked cozy little bar.  I order one of my usual drinks at a place like this - Bushmills on the rocks.  Nice pour at a good price!!!  The people were nice and the jut-box was playing proper tunes - what more can you ask for in a good dive?  

Although I love the Night Cap, I'd have to put this hidden gem on par with it, in terms of dive bars in the TL.  It is small, so if you have a big group, you might stick with one of the slightly larger bars in the area.  Although how packed the place is, I'm sure depends on the time/day.  We were there at 11:30pm on a Saturday.
author: Josh M.

description: Tiny dark smokey bar full of old people that are afraid of the internet, on the plus side everything is cheap. Next time I'll just smoke outside as I walk past.
author: Robert P.

description:
This bar is one of the few San Francisco bars that really qualifies as a dive bar.  It's smoky, there's video poker, an interesting mini library, grumpy old men and sweet sweet feisty female bartenders.  We came here not knowing exactly what to expect, but boy were we happy.  I love being able to smoke in a bar even though it sucks.  I also love feeling slightly out of place and having to work for the approval of old men.

I had a wonderful conversation with an old cowboy there who had some helpful tips on where to get a cowboy hat reshaped.  

Love love love
author: Erin D.

description: Lillian is great, the regulars are great. Smokey, small and so much fun. Apparently, every time I go there, I do the alcohol-induced habit of repeating myself, saying  "I love this bar!". Minus one star for idiot kids showing up once in awhile and making it amateur night, Go away!
author: November G.

description: If I needed a place to put a jukebox full of nostalgic soul and classic rock, I would probably dig a hole into a wall, hammer some seats into the ground, fill them with hard drinkin' men, and decorate the place with cheap liquor, sassy bartendresses and a big fucking tigers head. I wish I could take credit for inventing such a great place to put a great jukebox, but the brilliant inventors of the Geary club had the idea before I did, and they get to take the credit for best conversation bar of all time. sigh. I'll never do anything with my life.
author: Ian T.

description: Wow. Geary Club is rocking the old school bar feel and then some. Cheap drinks, silver foil ashtrays, varying levels of hardened drunks getting trolleyed in the darkness of an afternoon closed away in a bar without windows, and overseen by a stuffed fake tigers' head. I am pretty sure that tiger's head has seen a lot of things in it's time, things that my eyes are too innocent for. It is my first time in a smoking bar in SF - a surreal feeling in this hygienic, healthy world of ours - and I liked it.
author: Catriona C.

description: This is by far the "simplest" bar I've encountered in my seven years in SF. Its more like an enlarged cardboard box and its patrons reflect the decorum. Bars like this is where the hardened folk are ultimately drawn. The regular bartender seems usually to be coming down from a heroin bender. But she's friendly and real. Bars like this are mirrors into the soul. You take a pull of whiskey, drag of a cigarette, watch the pretense slip away. This is you. This is your life, actually. I love this bar. The same way I loved my first car. It was a piece of crap. But it worked. And it was mine. So, to wrap up, basically it's really ghetto but a great en route place to stop by before heading to the main event.
author: Seymour G.

description:
You'll love it or hate it. If you like to go out in the marina, don't come here. If you're from LA, don't come here. Did you dress up to go out? Then don't come here. Chances are, I don't want to see you there if you qualify for any of the above.

Cheap drinks, Lilian is cool, Harriet I don't think likes me so much, but I'm cool with that. There's 4 no smoking signs on the back of the entrance door in multiple languages, but I feel like it's there to be ironic. There is a lot of smoke in there so I try not to wear jackets in there that are a pain in the ass to get that smell out of. The ash trays are made of tin foil, they like to reuse them too instead of just throwing them out an making new ones (is that eco-friendly or lazy?).

I wouldn't go there if you want to meet "that someone special" but I would go there if you want cheap drinks and maybe meet some "characters".

It's not a trendy place, so if you're trying to impress people then you're wasting your time coming here cause no one cares.
author: Zach C.

description: Dimly lit and intimate. Great place for a drink before the evening rush.
author: John F.

description: This is a DIVE BAR!  Get it?  The Geary Club is one of the last hold-outs of the slowly shrinking Tenderloin. I affectionately call it God's Waiting Room. It's not a hip bar, and you should only enter if you don't mind cigarette smoke and if you really want to just drink and have a conversation. I love the bartenders! They're all women, and they won't put up with any crap!  For those of you who want music and surroundings and a possible hook-up, there are The Ambassador, Rye and Whiskey Thieves nearby.  Snarky hipsters will be dealt with accordingly by Harriet, who is usually quite sweet and charming! June is like a loveable Tenderloin Aunt Pitty-Pat.  I left my wallet there one night and had it returned completely intact ~ in the Tenderloin!  She even tracked down a mutual friend to call me about it!  Great for clandestine meetings! You'll not run into anyone you know here!
author: Carolyn T.

description: In my life, the best times I've had in bars were in bars with bartenders that were totally drunk. At 9PM.
author: Michael M.

description: This place is basically the size of a bedroom in SF....and if only bedroom in the city could be this cool. The bartender was a sassy older woman who probably had as much to drink that night as I had and why wouldn't you, really? Not to mention...the big tiger head, aluminum foil ashtrays and cheap cocktails. Awesome. This place makes me happy in ways that I didn't even know were possible.
author: Angela M.

description:
walking down the street we just randomly peeked into an open door and.. holy crap, there's a bar in there. no sign out front at all. we wander in and the place is pretty small but pretty lively. the bartender was super nice and it really seemed like the kind of place that would be perfect for hangin' out at and getting to know people. drinks were ridiculously cheap... our beers were 3$. they had a fun jukebox and the bartender would sing along to some of the songs. we asked the bartender what the place was called and she said that she guesses it's called Geary Bar, but really it's just no-name bar. there's something really cool about a bar that has no name. if our friends hadn't dragged us away, i would have wanted to stay longer...

(my resolution this year is to visit 50 new bars in SF.  read about it at: http://fiftybars.thisisvlad.com)
author: vlad k.

description:
T and I happened upon the Geary Club one night while trying to avoid the Edinburgh Castle, or the Hemlock Tavern, or whatever terrible bar our friends were at in that area. We used to call it the secret bar because it had no sign just an open dutch door. I was slightly upset when he spilled the beans on our little haven, but what can you do?
The best nights to go to the Geary Club are Fridays and Mondays, because that's when Lillian works. I really love Lillian. Lillian is a German powerhouse. She sings along to ABBA in a thick German accent. She calls us 'babies' and says we shouldn't drink as she pours us shots of Fernet. Oh, and the drinks are strong and cheap. Ask for an ashtray and you get a piece of tin foil. There is a stuffed tiger head above the bar that looks like it was taken from a Disneyland ride. Lillian hates that tiger. Any time I go to the Geary Club I know it's a commitment of staying until last call, which is sometimes as late as 2AM, and getting drunk. I love the Geary Club.
author: Daniella C.

description: Basically, a whole in the wall. No sign, just a single doorway of a narrow stucco windowless storefront. No smoking in San Fran, but anything goes in here. a very small bar with a very friendly older german bartender, my uncle sat on the bar with her as i took a picture while her hand rubbed dangerously close to his crotch. a good place to come early in your tenderloin evening. Ha-ra club right across the street.
author: Tim O.

description:
i like it, i love it, i want some more of it. it is the only bar where i have sat and talked with a man for half an hour and never once felt like he was trying to look down my shirt. surprising but true. 



that said, the last time i came here i got so drunk i was out of commission for a full 24 hours afterwards. as were both of my roommates.
author: Caitlin E.

description:
New to the neighborhood, this is the best bar I have stepped foot in yet.  This is a place to sit down, have a drink, have another drink, ....   well have about a dozen drinks and then stumble home. 

 For anyone who wants overly repetitive music, scanky women who can be mistaken for whores in this neighborhood, or douche bags in pink shirts with popped collars, DONT stop by this bar.  Go to North Beach.

The Geary Club has no windows or signs for a reason, so that anyone who doesn't need to be there, wont be there.

Well it is 11 a. on a Monday, might as well stop by right now and get a whiskey coffee to start the day.
author: Mike S.

description: Ok, we've been to a lot of dive bars, but this has to be the worse one I've ever set foot in.  We stopped in here after it was highly recommended, but I'm thinking people must have misunderstood us and thought we were looking for "dump" bars instead of "dive" bars.  Not only was the bartender rude, but the people were too.  Don't go to Geary Clud if you're looking a good time with locals - you won't find any happiness here!
author: Sabrina S.

description: Best place in the Tenderloin for a drink at 6am, Tuesday. This place is jumping weekday mornings and I don't want to know why.
author: patrick g.

description:
you know that sweet feeling inside when you went somewhere and had a yummy experience. ambiance, bartender, music, who knows.. but ya liked it. that feeling will cost $4.50 at geary club. and it will cost you double that at [insert name of snotty bar] down the street. 

sure i'm biased. i work at one of those snotty bars. 

but i would much rather be sitting at lillian's spot while she makes vague russglish innuendos I cannot understand.
author: Jeremi M.

description: There is definitely nothing else like this in San Francisco...or anywhere in the United States as far as I've found. One of my all time favorite bars, but I would not recommend going out and finding it. Rather, wait until one night where you're bar hopping in the area and the Geary Club finds you.
author: Jay F.

description: A great old man bar.  I was there Friday and got two free shots bought for me by two different strangers.  I was just sitting there.  It was the Russian (?) bar matron's birthday.  Wait, minus one star because the jukebox kinda sucks.
author: Ed B.

description: The Geary Club ROCKS...period. Thanks to Lillian, Harriet, Judy, Sara, June, and a jukebox which has remained in a 1970's time capsule..C'mon by and grab a cocktail...you'll be glad you did.
author: Susan L.

description:
this bar gets 5 stars.

this bar allows smoking inside, has a decent juke box, and the crowd isn't offensive. 

i was surprised when i lost my wallet there, the geary club wrote me a letter (like return address = The Geary Club).  they held my wallet for me for about 3 weeks.  personally i found that to be an amazing display of human kindness and will continue to support this bar.
author: megan t.

description: dimly-lit, tinfoil ashtrays, whiskey. a family dive bar. semi-decent jukebox. double order of sadness cocktails, and one for the road. i love it.
author: John M.

description: if you like dives you will like the Geary Club. Not only is there a fake stuffed tiger head front and center, but bartender I had didn't seem to know how to enunciate...she was more slurry than Paula Abdul and Anna Nicole combined. She provided much entertainment singing and dancing around and telling stories. she explained to us that she hates "getting a bad nutt," In reference to "life is like a box of chocolate"you never know if your gonna get a bad nut since it is in a shell??? Hahahaha I'm still laughing. One thing she did know how to do well was make a stiff drink and aluminum foil ash trays. My Sailor Jerry and coke with a twist of line was 3/4 SJ and 1/4 coke. Apparently you are "allowed" to smoke in there (that's why I left) so the bartender made everyone foil ash trays by molding foil around the base of a coffee can. Genius. The jukebox was super cool, oldies and country, 5 for a dolla. If your looking for a place to meet pretty people and hook up you best go somewhere else. If you want to get down to business and drink, this is your spot. I think most everyone in there was a professional drinker. I felt right at home.
author: Juliana M.

description: definitely one of my favorite places in the city.  known as 'the secret bar' to me and my friends, this is our home base and refueling stop on any good night out.  the bartender is hilarious, and always happy to pass out an aluminum foil ashtray or make us a vodka-tab for $2, all the while stacking up great songs on the jukebox and playing the video game they have set up in the corner.  we went to their holiday party, and while i was sitting on the sketchy santa's lap i couldn't think of anything to ask for because all of my dreams had already come true.
author: ali l.

description: this place reminds me of the scene in the french connection when popeye wakes up with his head on the bar at first light.  its that kind of place and it rules.
author: Markus B.

description: cheap drinks, old school bartendress and BOOBIE TOUCH! good for old friends, not so for new.
author: Clover Dan ..

description: The greatest dive bar in the Tenderloin area. You'll know why when you go. No frills, no pool table, no specials - just a row of stools and the ladies keeping your glass full. Well, the jukebox is something frilled, I guess, but there's nothing on it from after, like, 1990. What satisfies is its utter lack of pretense, the happy hour prices at any hour, and the decor that changes seasonally but always includes one dusty and very unconvincing tiger head. Couple this with the lack of any sign indicating the name of the business (legend has it the sign caught fire, taking a nearby tree with it) and you start to see why young locals dub it "no name" or "tiger bar". But it's thankfully mostly youth free, just the normal neighborhood working folk getting off at 6 and staying until the limit's reached. Definitely a winner for the frugal, as you can get a G&T for under $3 and you never pay more than $6 for anything, even top shelf liquors.
author: Michael K.

description: good jukebox, smells like smoke, always easy to get a drink.
author: christopher a.

description: The Geary Club is one of the few bars downtown that open up at the crack of dawn.  Tucked away between two storefronts on Geary Boulevard between Hyde and Leavenworth, the club is easy to miss.  The entire bar is just that...a long wooden bar with a jukebox to the right as you enter and a bathroom in the back.  The tiger's head mounted above the bar makes for a nice conversation piece.
author: Joe C.
